text:
How Do You Think Technology Affects Dating?

Have you had any experience with dating? Have you ever used dating apps? If so, what has it been like for you? If not, why not?

How do you think technology — like apps, Netflix, social media and texting — affects dating and relationships? In your opinion, does it improve or worsen romantic interactions? How so?

How Do You Think Technology Affects Dating?

Have you had any experience with dating? Have you ever used dating apps? If so, what has it been like for you? If not, why not?

How do you think technology — like apps, Netflix, social media and texting — affects dating and relationships? In your opinion, does it improve or worsen romantic interactions? How so?

---

Technology makes dating worse. It promotes a superficial and shallow view of people as commodities. Rather than seeing people as complex and wonderful, we are presented with a limited and basic message that says, "here is what I'm good for."

How Do You Think Technology Affects Dating?

Have you had any experience with dating? Have you ever used dating apps? If so, what has it been like for you? If not, why not?

How do you think technology — like apps, Netflix, social media and texting — affects dating and relationships? In your opinion, does it improve or worsen romantic interactions? How so?

---

Technology makes dating worse. It promotes a superficial and shallow view of people as commodities. Rather than seeing people as complex and wonderful, we are presented with a limited and basic message that says, "here is what I'm good for." It promotes a shallowness in which we can glance over the person and make a judgment of them based on their profile picture, or how they present themselves on a dating app.

How Do You Think Technology Affects Dating?

Have you had any experience with dating? Have you ever used dating apps? If so, what has it been like for you? If not, why not?

How do you think technology — like apps, Netflix, social media and texting — affects dating and relationships? In your opinion, does it improve or worsen romantic interactions? How so?

---

Technology makes dating worse. It promotes a superficial and shallow view of people as commodities. Rather than seeing people as complex and wonderful, we are presented with a limited and basic message that says, "here is what I'm good for." It promotes a shallowness in which we can glance over the person and make a judgment of them based on their profile picture, or how they present themselves on a dating app.



We lose opportunities to have real, meaningful, in-depth relationships where we can get to know someone in the "slow lane".

Rather than seeing people as complex and wonderful, we are presented with a limited and basic message that says, "here is what I'm good for." It promotes a shallowness in which we can glance over the person and make a judgment of them based on their profile picture, or how they present themselves on a dating app.

We lose opportunities to have real, meaningful, in-depth relationships where we can get to know someone in the "slow lane".

How Do You Think Technology Affects Dating?

Have you had any experience with dating? Have you ever used dating apps? If so, what has it been like for you? If not, why not?

How do you think technology — like apps, Netflix, social media and texting — affects dating and relationships? In your opinion, does it improve or worsen romantic interactions? How so?

---

Technology makes dating worse. It promotes a superficial and shallow view of people as commodities. Rather than seeing people as complex and wonderful, we are presented with a limited and basic message that says, "here is what I'm good for." It promotes a shallowness in which we can glance over the person and make a judgment of them based on their profile picture, or how they present themselves on a dating app.

We lose opportunities to have real, meaningful, in-depth relationships where we can get to know someone in the "slow lane". 

Taking time to get to know someone is more meaningful than simply swiping right or left on a dating app.

Technology makes dating worse. It promotes a superficial and shallow view of people as commodities. Rather than seeing people as complex and wonderful, we are presented with a limited and basic message that says, "here is what I'm good for." It promotes a shallowness in which we can glance over the person and make a judgment of them based on their profile picture, or how they present themselves on a dating app.

We lose opportunities to have real, meaningful, in-depth relationships where we can get to know someone in the "slow lane".  Taking time to get to know someone is more meaningful than simply swiping right or left on a dating app.

How Do You Think Technology Affects Dating?

Have you had any experience with dating? Have you ever used dating apps? If so, what has it been like for you? If not, why not?

How do you think technology — like apps, Netflix, social media and texting — affects dating and relationships? In your opinion, does it improve or worsen romantic interactions? How so?

---

Technology makes dating worse. It promotes a superficial and shallow view of people as commodities. Rather than seeing people as complex and wonderful, we are presented with a limited and basic message that says, "here is what I'm good for." It promotes a shallowness in which we can glance over the person and make a judgment of them based on their profile picture, or how they present themselves on a dating app.

We lose opportunities to have real, meaningful, in-depth relationships where we can get to know someone in the "slow lane".  Taking time to get to know someone is more meaningful than simply swiping right or left on a dating app. Technology also encourages dishonesty and being manipulative, especially with how easy it is to delete or avoid people on social media and dating apps.

Technology makes dating worse. It promotes a superficial and shallow view of people as commodities. Rather than seeing people as complex and wonderful, we are presented with a limited and basic message that says, "here is what I'm good for." It promotes a shallowness in which we can glance over the person and make a judgment of them based on their profile picture, or how they present themselves on a dating app.

We lose opportunities to have real, meaningful, in-depth relationships where we can get to know someone in the "slow lane".  Taking time to get to know someone is more meaningful than simply swiping right or left on a dating app. Technology also encourages dishonesty and being manipulative, especially with how easy it is to delete or avoid people on social media and dating apps.  "Ghosting" is commonplace-you don't feel like listening? Just never reply back, no explanation needed, zero repercussions.

Technology seems to replace real, deep relationships with superficial ones.

How do you think technology — like apps, Netflix, social media and texting — affects dating and relationships? In your opinion, does it improve or worsen romantic interactions? How so?

---

Technology makes dating worse. It promotes a superficial and shallow view of people as commodities. Rather than seeing people as complex and wonderful, we are presented with a limited and basic message that says, "here is what I'm good for." It promotes a shallowness in which we can glance over the person and make a judgment of them based on their profile picture, or how they present themselves on a dating app.

We lose opportunities to have real, meaningful, in-depth relationships where we can get to know someone in the "slow lane".  Taking time to get to know someone is more meaningful than simply swiping right or left on a dating app. Technology also encourages dishonesty and being manipulative, especially with how easy it is to delete or avoid people on social media and dating apps.  "Ghosting" is commonplace-you don't feel like listening? Just never reply back, no explanation needed, zero repercussions. 

Technology seems to replace real, deep relationships with superficial ones. Because there is such a rapid decline in value of one's interactions on social media, one spends more time on it and less time searching for a real relationship with another person.

How Do You Think Technology Affects Dating?

Have you had any experience with dating? Have you ever used dating apps? If so, what has it been like for you? If not, why not?

How do you think technology — like apps, Netflix, social media and texting — affects dating and relationships? In your opinion, does it improve or worsen romantic interactions? How so?

---

Technology makes dating worse. It promotes a superficial and shallow view of people as commodities. Rather than seeing people as complex and wonderful, we are presented with a limited and basic message that says, "here is what I'm good for." It promotes a shallowness in which we can glance over the person and make a judgment of them based on their profile picture, or how they present themselves on a dating app.

We lose opportunities to have real, meaningful, in-depth relationships where we can get to know someone in the "slow lane".  Taking time to get to know someone is more meaningful than simply swiping right or left on a dating app. Technology also encourages dishonesty and being manipulative, especially with how easy it is to delete or avoid people on social media and dating apps.  "Ghosting" is commonplace-you don't feel like listening? Just never reply back, no explanation needed, zero repercussions. 

Technology seems to replace real, deep relationships with superficial ones. Because there is such a rapid decline in value of one's interactions on social media, one spends more time on it and less time searching for a real relationship with another person. A lot of people act like movie characters, piecing together a picture of themselves that they wish was true, rather than expressing who they truly are.

A lot of people seem to be on the hunt for perfection in the things and people they idolize.

It promotes a shallowness in which we can glance over the person and make a judgment of them based on their profile picture, or how they present themselves on a dating app.

We lose opportunities to have real, meaningful, in-depth relationships where we can get to know someone in the "slow lane". Many people seem to be on the hunt for perfection in the things and people they idolize. They are constantly comparing others to a perfect image they have created in their minds or a standard they've set.

Nothing is ever good enough, or someone is always doing better than you.

We focus on finding attention, likes, good pics-instead of finding real, meaningful people to relate to. It's no wonder why there's an increase in anxiety and depression.

It promotes a shallowness in which we can glance over the person and make a judgment of them based on their profile picture, or how they present themselves on a dating app.

We lose opportunities to have real, meaningful, in-depth relationships where we can get to know someone in the "slow lane".  Taking time to get to know someone is more meaningful than simply swiping right or left on a dating app. Technology also encourages dishonesty and being manipulative, especially with how easy it is to delete or avoid people on social media and dating apps.  "Ghosting" is commonplace-you don't feel like listening? Just never reply back, no explanation needed, zero repercussions. 

Technology seems to replace real, deep relationships with superficial ones. Because there is such a rapid decline in value of one's interactions on social media, one spends more time on it and less time searching for a real relationship with another person. A lot of people act like movie characters, piecing together a picture of themselves that they wish was true, rather than expressing who they truly are.

Many people seem to be on the hunt for perfection in the things and people they idolize. They are constantly comparing others to a perfect image they have created in their minds or a standard they've set. On social media and dating apps, you see constant comparisons and negativity. Nothing is ever good enough, or someone is always doing better than you.

We focus on finding attention, likes, good pics-instead of finding real, meaningful people to relate to.  It's no wonder why there's an increase in anxiety and depression. We are so far removed from natural human contact, and our sense of security and well being are suffering because of it.
